asked the Minister for Science and Consumer Affairs, upon notice:

item.para: Has his attention been drawn to a library computer system which has now been installed at La Trobe University and of the efforts by the head of that University's Library Technical Services Division to interest other institutions in sharing the use of the facilities that will be available at the University.
If so, will Government Departments take advantage of this system in preference to developing their own systems independently.
How does the CSIRO's computer network co-ordinate with this and similar types of computer information systems.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I am advised that:

item.para: The announcement of the La Trobe University Library's computerised 'on-line cataloguing system' (copy attached) has been noted with interest, and the further development of the system will be watched carefully.

The application of computers to this important area of library operation in La Trobe University is however only one of the many such applications now being developed by libraries in Australia. Indeed, since 1970 there has been an association of individuals and institutions concerned in this field: the Library Automated System Information Exchange (LAS IE), which has approximately 200 members. Although this is a matter for my colleague the Special Minister of State, as I understand it the extent to which common computer networking can develop among Australian libraries, including that of La Trobe, may depend on the results of feasibility studies on an 'Australian Library-based Information System (ALBIS)'. These studies, which are now commencing in the National Library of Australia, are intended to provide a national framework within which all library and information services operate in a co-ordinated way.
The CSIRO computer network, strictly defined, is not connected for library or scientific information purposes to any other networks at the present time.

quote.para: However, the library and information services of CSIRO are freely available to the Australian community outside CSIRO. This is ensured through a vigorous inter-library loan activity (CSIRO lends considerably more material than it borrows); through the marshalling of the scientific and technical expertise of CSIRO scientists in answering the tens of thousands of inquiries received from all sections of the Australian community; and through offering subscriptions to CSIRO's computerised information service on the same basis to outside subscribers as to CSIRO 's own scientists.

Co-ordination of CSIRO activities with other national initiatives in these fields is effected through the participation of CSIRO on all the relevant national and other professional bodies. Such bodies are the Interdepartmental Committee of the Australian Library-based Information System (Albi) the National Library's Advisory Council on Science and Technology; the Australian Advisory Council on Bibliographical Services (AACOBS); the Library Association of Australia and others. CSIRO policy is to collaborate with ail library and information services in Australia or overseas where such collaboration may be of mutual benefit or in the national interest, and to co-ordinate and further develop its own services wherever appropriate within the general framework of the Albi program mentioned above.
A BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF LA TROBE UNIVERSITY LIBRARY'S ON-LINE CATALOGUING SUPPORT SYSTEM

Since the inception of the Australian MARC Record Service (Arms) La Trobe University Library has been planning and developing a system designed to permit on-line editing of MARC records obtained selectively from Arms and an automatic card production system.

The editing module is now fully functional. The programs of this module provide for the conversion of the original MARC record to be converted into a processing record, which in fact is a MARC record stripped from inessential information and formatted in a way which allows for easy editing- that is deleting, changing and adding new information by cataloguers or data-preparation personnel. This record can be edited either directly on the screen by a cataloguer, or it can be printed in the form of a worksheet to be marked by a cataloguer, which is then used by a terminal operator for editing the processing record. The latter is then ready to be re-formatted for output in the shape of catalogue cards, book-form catalogues, computer output microfilm, etc.

The output module- the medium is cards- is being implemented in two phases. Phase 1, which is now operational, consists of the software required for the production of full and finished card sets. Phase 2 will extend this software so that instead of sets, the cards will be printed in presorted files which will correspond to the Library's own files Programming for Phase 2 has commenced.

As already mentioned, the system is- as indeed all systems currently under development or planned are- in an on-line mode. All programs have been written in FORTRAN with some segments in Macro-assembler. Processing is done on the University's DECsystem-10. Terminals used include an ADM-2 visual display unit, manufactured by the U.S. firm of Lear Ziegler Inc., marketed in Australia by AWA, and a Term i net 1200 printer terminal, with a printing speed of 120 characters per second. The latter is manufactured in the U.S. by General Electric.

The economic impact of the system is expected to be felt chiefly in the area of clerical operations associated with card production, such as typing masters, finishing cards, distribution, presort ing, etc. The effect on professional work is much harder to predict, especially where the clerical components in cataloguers' work is already reduced to a minimum. Nevertheless some prediction can be made. For example there is much less manual transcription than in conventional cataloguing, with a further result of reduction in proof reading load which is considerable in a cataloguing operation.

Another relevant consideration is the coverage of MARC. It is expected that when the system becomes fully operational about 40-50% of the Library's intake, that is about 7500-9000 titles, will be processed by the system. However, the coverage of MARC is continually expanding so that this figure is expected to increase gradually. Moreover, it is envisaged that the system will be extended to accept input of all cataloguing produced in the Library.

Long-term plans call for extending the system both vertically as well as horizontally. In respect of the former, the most important project will be the automation of the authority files, enabling a completely automated catalogue production. Horizontal expansion will result in an automated ordering/in-process control system, which may include a selection module. A rather sophisticated book fund accounting module, which has been operational since early 1975, will be incorporated into this sub-system.
G. Ste cher Associate Librarian, Technical Services.
